page.title: 01Balloch, Upper R. Stinchar
page.content: The narrow partly arable flood-plains of the upper River Stinchar are flanked by middle-aged conifers of Balloch section of Carrick Forest, planted on the higher peaty moorland and on the steep sides of the glen. From above, the narrow glen with varied species of conifers can be quite spectacular. Carrick Forest is part of the extensive Galloway Forest Park. The Ballock and Dalquhairn burns join the Stinchar in square 5, and associated fairly indifferent arable ground provides sites for 5 or 6 once extensive sheep farms. Several of these, with afforestation have been reduced to agricultural holdings. Some still graze hardy hill sheep & Galloway black cattle on the high hills above the tree-line. Aldinna & White Rue were until recently Forest Worker's Holdings, whose tenants
